items.title: Associate renderer with loader
items.body:
I need to manually use a loader object. It appears I need to use the following code to make partials work:

```
    self.loader = pystache.loader.Loader(
        extension='txt', search_dirs=search_dirs, file_encoding='utf-8')
    self.mustache = pystache.Renderer(
        file_extension='txt', search_dirs=search_dirs, file_encoding='utf-8')
```

That is a lot of duplicaton. I feel like I should be able to say:

```
  mustache = pystache.Renderer(loader=loader)
```

items.title: Pystache not following spec for dictionaries?
items.body:
Based on the "Non-False Values" section of `mustache(5)`...

> Non-False Values
> 
> When the value is non-false but not a list, it will be used as the context for a single 
> rendering of the block.

I figured that given this dictionary:

```
session = {
  'visited': True,
   '_accessed_time': 1378009889.819518, 
  '_creation_time': 1378009571.726927,
}
```

And this template:

```
{{#session}}
Value of `visited`: {{visited}}
{{/session}}
```

And rendering it like this:

```
pystache.render(template, { 'session': session })
```

That it would expand `{{visited}}` to `True`...but it appears to be
treating `{{#session}}` as a _list_, and is iterating over the keys.
Am I misreading the _mustache_ documentation, or is _pystache_ not
conforming?

Thanks!

items.title: object methods aren't getting called when the object is a string
items.body:
The interpolation spec says,

```
This tag's content names the data to replace the tag.  A single period (`.`)
indicates that the item currently sitting atop the context stack should be
used; otherwise, name resolution is as follows:

1) Split the name on periods; the first part is the name to resolve, any
remaining parts should be retained.

2) Walk the context stack from top to bottom, finding the first context
that is a) a hash containing the name as a key OR b) an object responding
to a method with the given name.

3) If the context is a hash, the data is the value associated with the
name.

4) If the context is an object, the data is the value returned by the
method with the given name.

5) If any name parts were retained in step 1, each should be resolved
against a context stack containing only the result from the former
resolution.  If any part fails resolution, the result should be considered
falsey, and should interpolate as the empty string.

Data should be coerced into a string (and escaped, if appropriate) before
interpolation.
```

I interpret this to mean that '{{person.upper}}' in the context {'person': 'Mom"'} should find the key 'person' in the context, use 'Mom' as the data and place it on the context stack, and then search that object (a string) for a method named 'upper', invoke that method, and place the returned value ('MOM') on the top of the context stack.

Note that '{{#person}}{{.}}{{/person}}' returns 'Mom', indicating that 'Mom' is indeed on the top of the context stack.  However, both '{{person.upper}}' and  '{{#person}}{{upper}}{{/person}}' return an empty string, indicating that method resolution and invocation is not being performed.

items.title: Handlebars compatibility
items.body:
Apologies if this has been discussed before, but I didn't see it any past issues. I was wondering if support for helpers has been considered for greater compatibility with Handlebars templates.

I understand that implementing the Mustache spec precisely is the number one goal. However, since pystache already implements most of Handlebars, it would be great to have this as an option (disabled by default of course). I very quickly hacked in support for non-block helpers in under 10 lines of code and all existing tests still pass.

Just curious if there's any interest in this and I can clean that up and send a pull request to continue further discussion. Thanks!

items.title: pystache on windows adds an extra cr to every line
items.body:
pystache on Windows seems to convert every CR (hex 0D) to two CRs. For example, every line ending in 0D0A after conversion will end in 0D0D0A. 

Here's a test script:

rom pystache.loader import Loader
from pystache.renderer import Renderer

loader = Loader(extension='txt')
template = loader.load_name(r'test')
renderer = Renderer()
with open(r'test_out', 'w') as text_file:
    text_file.write(renderer.render(template))

Where test.txt looks like:

This text has only one line with a crlf at the end.

items.title: mustache template variables with dot fail to 'render'
items.body:
Eg: 

>>> mydict
{'catalina_home': '/opt/software/tomcat7', 'catalina.home': '/opt/software/tomcat7'}
>>> pystache.render('Hello {{catalina.home}}', mydict)
u'Hello '
Not sure if this is a limitation / against the mustache template language grammar or an issue with pystache implementation.

items.title: Deal with pandoc center-aligning images
items.body:
Running pandoc on our Markdown files adds--

```
:align: center
```

to images, whereas we want images to be left-aligned.  We should have a programmatic way to deal with this (i.e. instead of manually deleting the alignment directive).  Also see [this thread](https://groups.google.com/d/topic/pandoc-discuss/rxjyzxx9oF0/discussion).

items.title: pystache DELIMITERS defaults
items.body:
I'm currently using pystache to generate templated C code (rather than say HTML code), and have done the following:

pystache.defaults.MISSING_TAGS = 'strict'
pystache.defaults.TAG_ESCAPE = lambda u: u

I'm wondering if that is an intended way of doing things?

I tried to also do this:

pystache.defaults.DELIMITERS = ('[[', ']]')

However, that doesn't work as parser.py does "from pystache.defaults import DELIMITERS", so any changes don't get picked up.

When I change the code to "from pystache import defaults" and "defaults.DELIMITERS" rather than just "DELIMITERS", everything is fine.

Anyway, just wondering if it was your intention that the user can configure things through defaults (if so, I'll send a pull request), or if in this case I should be manually constructing Parser and Renderer objects.

What is the best way to handle this?

 43     if isinstance(context, dict):
 44         # Then we consider the argument a "hash" for the purposes of the spec.
 45         #
 46         # We do a membership test to avoid using exceptions for flow control

items.title: Add Renderer.render_name()
items.body:
The `Renderer` class currently lets one render a template given a template string, object instance, or path (via the `render()` and `render_path()` methods respectively), but it does not let one render a template by name directly (using the `search_dirs` attribute, etc).

We should add `Renderer.render_name()`.

items.title: Release v0.5.3 to PyPI
items.body: See [HISTORY](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/development/HISTORY.md) for changes.

items.title: Handle lambda section values returning non-ascii, non-unicode
items.body:
The code currently doesn't handle a lambda section value returning a non-ascii, non-unicode string.  Here is a test case:

```
>>> u = u'abcd\u00e9'
>>> print u
abcdé
>>> s = u.encode('utf8')
>>> template = '{{#lambda}}{{/lambda}}'
>>> context = {'lambda': lambda text: s}
>>> from pystache import Renderer
>>> renderer = Renderer(string_encoding='utf8')
>>> renderer.render(template, context)
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 4: ordinal not in range(128)
>>> 
```

items.title: Push v0.5.2 in master to PyPI
items.body: This can be done after a few days or so but should be done within a week.

items.title: Match spec expectation for partials not found
items.body: A missing partial should render as the empty string.  See this issue: https://github.com/mustache/spec/issues/20

items.title: List of lambdas not processed correctly for sections
items.body:
Here is a test case:

```
>>> import pystache
>>> template = "<{{#lambdas}}planet{{/lambdas}}>"
>>> context = {'planet': 'Earth','lambdas': [lambda text: "~{{%s}}~" % text, lambda text: "#{{%s}}#" % text]}
>>> pystache.render(template, context)
u'<planetplanet>'
```

The correct value is `u'<~Earth~#Earth#>'`.  This test case was also submitted to the Mustache spec as part of this [pull request](https://github.com/mustache/spec/pull/47).

items.title: Section lambdas mistakenly pushed onto context stack
items.body:
Here is a test case:

```
>>> import pystache
>>> context = {'foo': 'bar', 'lambda': (lambda text: "{{.}}")}
>>> template = '{{#foo}}{{#lambda}}blah{{/lambda}}{{/foo}}'
>>> pystache.render(template, context)
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
TypeError: <lambda>() takes exactly 1 argument (0 given)
>>>
```

The expected value is `u'bar'`.

I submitted to the Mustache spec a [pull request](https://github.com/mustache/spec/pull/47) that adds a test to cover this case.

items.title: Documentation needed: how to specify a template path?
items.body:
I found Pystache via http://duganchen.ca/single-page-web-app-architecture-done-right/ which uses this declaration to specify a template path:

```
pystache.View.template_path = settings.MEDIA_ROOT
```

With the move to 0.5.0 and the removal of the View class, this of course no longer works. The examples mix `*.py` and `*.mustache` files in the same folder, but I need to put my templates in a separate folder. The documentation for the library should specify how to do this.

Thanks!

items.title: Missing tag values always treated as empty
items.body:
It would be great (as apparently is the case in the Ruby moustache version) to have the option of errors generated when tags are missing.

In fact, since pystache uses hasattr to check for tags, this can cause errors to be lost if the tag is returned from a property function. Any exceptions generated by property functions are swallowed and pystache treats the tag as being unset.

items.title: Release v0.5.1 with Python 3.x support
items.body: Release v0.5.1 with support for Python 3.

items.title: Allow testing of all Python versions using a single script
items.body: Thinking about using [tox](http://pypi.python.org/pypi/tox) for this.

items.title: Make Pystache work "out of the box" with Python 3
items.body: The current tests (including doctests and spec tests) all pass now with Python 3 after automatic conversion with `2to3`.  We just need to get it working "out of the box" now via appropriate changes to setup.py, etc.

items.title: Don't require nose for tests
items.body:
If we can do test discovery without use of `nose`, then we should be able to run unit tests for Python 3 (issue #104) and pre-Python 2.4 (issue #103) more easily.

With regard to Python 3, my preliminary attempts to pass [`test_suite = 'nose.collector'`](http://readthedocs.org/docs/nose/en/latest/setuptools_integration.html#nosetests-command) to `setup()` for use with [Distribute's](http://packages.python.org/distribute/python3.html#distribute-as-help-during-porting) `python setup test` seemed to have issues.

Specifically, this task is to set things up in accordance with the instructions [here](http://packages.python.org/distribute/setuptools.html#test), namely to wrap the project's tests in a `unittest` test suite.

items.title: Auto-run 2to3 when unit testing from Python 3
items.body:
We should update our test harness so that it runs `2to3` automatically when running tests from Python 3.  For example, we could try the approach described [here](http://packages.python.org/distribute/python3.html) of using the `use_2to3` keyword argument to `setup()`.

This might require us to do "manual" test discovery without use of `nose` since my preliminary experiments in passing [`test_suite = 'nose.collector'`](http://readthedocs.org/docs/nose/en/latest/setuptools_integration.html#nosetests-command) to `setup()` for Distribute's `test` command seem to reveal issues.

items.title: Python 3 support: get all tests passing after 2to3
items.body:
I started this process [here](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/tree/issue-102-support-python3).  The spec tests now all pass with Python 3.2.  About 25 other failures remain.

Here is the command for the conversion:

```
2to3 --write --nobackups --no-diffs .
```

We should also make it so that the converted code is tested automatically by our test runner, e.g. using the strategy described in the [Distribute documentation](http://packages.python.org/distribute/python3.html#distribute-as-help-during-porting). [Edit: I added issue #104 for this latter point.]

items.title: Deploy v0.5.0 to PyPI
items.body: We should push v0.5.0 from master to PyPI after an initial waiting period (e.g. after a week).

items.title: Mustache spec v1.1.2 compliance
items.body:
Pystache (master and development) is currently compliant with Mustache spec 1.0.3. The latest spec version tag is v1.1.2.

I have a branch (from development) which implements v1.1.2 compliance. Namely, it implements dot notation. It also updates the specs submodule to the v1.1.2 tag. All tests are passing.

My branch is located at https://github.com/rbp/pystache/tree/spec-1.1.2-compliant . I am quite new to mustache, so please let me know if I should do a pull request, or if you need further changes. Given that this is a relatively simple (if backwards-incompatible) patch, and one that implements a very handy feature, I'd be glad to see it through.

items.title: Deploy v0.4.1 to PyPI (support for Python 2.4)
items.body: See title.

items.title: second list gets all its contents escaped
items.body:
Using the current git version: ``` >>> pystache.render("{{#p1}}
{{/p1}} {{#p2}}
{{/p2}}", dict(p1=[1,2], p2=[3,4])) Markup(u'

<div><div>') ``` I was expecting ``` "

" ```

items.title: Changing delimiters should only affect the upcoming text.
items.body:
I am not sure if/how this issue relates to issue #84

using the dataset `{"a":"a", "b":"b", "c":"c", "d":"d", "e":"e", "f":"f"}`

The following:

```
<%a%>
{{b}}
{{=<% %>=}}
<%c%>
{{d}}
<%={{ }}=%>
{{e}}
<%f%>
```

Should result in:

```
<%a%>
b
c
{{d}}
e
<%f%>
```

But it actually results in:

```
a
b
c
d
e
<%f%>
```

This is very bad if you want to use both server-side and clien-side templates within one file. I checked the code and couldn't think of a quick-fix because this bug is inherent in the way the parser works: just search the whole template for the first match to a regex, replace this match then restart, from the beginning. It would rather need to restart from the previous match position.

items.title: Partials Are HTML escaped if a section is in the template
items.body:
## Steps to reproduce Take the following templates: `partial.mustache` ```

Hello, I'm a partial. {{a}}

``` `middle_nosection.mustache` ``` {{> partial }} hello, I'm the middle without a section ``` `middle_section.mustache` ``` {{> partial }} hello, I'm the middle with a section {{#b}} * {{n}} {{/b}} ``` run pystache against both templates, and inspect the output: ## Output ```

Hello, I'm a partial 123

hello, I'm the middle without a section ``` For the section: ``` <h2> Hello, I'm a partial 123 </h2> hello, I'm the middle with a section * 1 * 2 ``` ## Expected That both partials are rendered the same way (no escaping)

items.title: bug in delimiters changing
items.body:
I found what changing delimiters with {{= works fine until you don't try to work with nested syntax.
Just try this:

> > > import pystache
> > > print pystache.render("{{#n}} {{test}} {{/n}}", {'n':{'test':'works'}})
> > > works 
> > > print pystache.render("{{=[[ ]]=}} [[#n]] [[test]] [[/n]]", {'n':{'test':'works'}})
> > > Traceback (most recent call last):
> > >   File "test.py", line 3, in <module>
> > >     print pystache.render("{{=[[ ]]=}} [[#n]] [[test]] [[/n]]", {'n':{'test':'works'}})
> > >   File "/Users/bobuk/,misc/pystache/pystache/**init**.py", line 8, in render
> > >     return Template(template, context).render()
> > >   File "/Users/bobuk/,misc/pystache/pystache/template.py", line 172, in render
> > >     result = self._render_tags(template)
> > >   File "/Users/bobuk/,misc/pystache/pystache/template.py", line 113, in _render_tags
> > >     func = self.modifiers[tag_type]
> > > KeyError: '#'

items.title: Pystache version in PyPI is _really_ old (May 2010)
items.body: It looks like lot of time passed since last PyPI release. I think it's a good idea to release there as often as possible.

items.title: Inverted Sections Don't Support Hashes
items.body:
> > > pystache.render('{{#x}}YES{{/x}}{{^x}}NO{{/x}}', {'x': {'foo': 42}})
> > > 'YESNO'

The output SHOULD be 'YES', not 'YESNO'

items.title: Do not call methods on strings
items.body:
See the comment for [this commit](https://github.com/schallis/pystache/commit/71779446be442085be0cd408dfa81ad389165cca) by @schallis:

> Removed the ability to call methods on strings
> 
> Whilst the ability to revert to calling getattr() on an arbitrary object can
> be useful, this can cause problems when the intended variable appears later in
> the context than an object with a similarly named attribute.
> 
> For example, take the following context:
> 
> ```
> ['The cat sat on the mat', {'count': 5, 'color': "blue"}]
> ```
> 
> In this instance, calling `{{count}}` in the template would return the count
> method of the string which is not what we intended.

items.title: Quotes are not escaped
items.body:
This may be an error in mustache, or a misconception of mine, but why are quotes (in attribute values, but optionally everywhere else too) not escaped? ``` >>> import pystache >>> pystache.render(u'
Hover
', {'title': u'The "mustache" library'}) u'
Hover
' ``` I expected ``` u'
Hover
' ``` which matches the output (sans `u`, of course) I get from [mustache.js](https://github.com/janl/mustache.js).

items.title: Pystache can't access outer variables in loops
items.body:
The following fails, but should work (and the equivalent does work with mustache.js)

> > > import pystache
> > > template = "{{#loop}}{{inner}} {{outer}}{{/loop}}"
> > > data = {
> > > ... "loop": [{"inner": "INNER"}],
> > > ... "outer": "OUTER"
> > > ... }
> > > pystache.render(template, data)
> > > u'INNER '

Tested with 0.3.1

items.title: Create release v0.5.0 from development branch
items.body:
We should merge development to master at some point and create a new release -- perhaps v.0.5.0.

There is just a bit more code cleanup that I think should be done (renderengine.py and view.py) as well as summarizing the changes better in the history file.

items.title: Merge @pvande's parsing logic
items.body:
This issue is to merge @pvande's "spec compliant" code from [here](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/tree/e06bed513dd380bb7760a2bf69af2f7bc0edf405) into the development branch.  Spec tests and unit tests should continue to work after the merge.

Also, we should check that speed shouldn't get _too_ much slower -- though getting slower is definitely okay.  We're not nearly at the point of worrying about speed.

Regarding speed, here are some numbers from running the development branch's `python tests/benchmark.py 10000` on various branches (numbers are in seconds):

master (current):

```
Benchmarking: 10000x

1.02371788025
4.70996713638
```

development (current):

```
Benchmarking: 10000x

0.930554151535
3.0906059742
```

pvande (e06bed513dd380bb7760a2bf69af2f7bc0edf405):

```
Benchmarking: 10000x

2.33062005043
12.1700999737
```

So what we'll be merging is probably on the order of 2-3 times slower than master, which seems fine to me.

items.title: Rudimentary benchmarking capabilities
items.body:
As we make the parser in the development branch more compliant with the spec, it would be nice if we had some rudimentary benchmarking capabilities.  This would be useful for comparing any new parser implementations (e.g. what's currently in the spec-compliant branch) with what's currently in master.  This would be so that we don't, say, make the new implementation an order of magnitude worse than what we currently have (a concern that was expressed [here](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/pull/39#issuecomment-2897058), for example).

Ideally, the benchmark test would be both forward and backward compatible, so that we can, say, run the test against the implementation in the master branch though the benchmark script would reside in the development branch.

items.title: Add Renderer.render_path()
items.body: Adding `Renderer.render_path(template_path, ...)` to Renderer's API should make it easier to play around with pystache.  For example, it would have helped [this person](http://librelist.com/browser//pystache/2011/12/19/pystache-flask-and-loading-templates/).  Also, adding this functionality to the Renderer class will help in implementing issue #70.

items.title: Default to running unit tests without spec tests
items.body: Since we have so many spec-test failures right now, let's default to running the unit tests without them but have an option to include them.

items.title: Put the template reading code into a Reader class
items.body: The Loader class is currently responsible for both finding and reading templates.  There are cases where we only need to read a template and not find one though (i.e. we are given the path), so it makes sense to separate this logic off into its own class.  This will also aid us in thinking about the right API.

items.title: Bring the spec tests into the development branch
items.body: This can be done by merging the first couple commits of the spec-compliant branch.

items.title: Support Renderer.render(object, context)
items.body: Support passing an object to `renderer.render()`.  The Renderer class can employ logic similar to the View's (constructing the template name, etc) to locate the template.

items.title: Remove markupsafe dependency
items.body: Markupsafe is currently used in just two places in the code: (1) to provide [`Renderer.__init__()`](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/development/pystache/renderer.py#L91) with a custom escape function, and (2) to wrap the return value of `Renderer.render()` in a custom class [in the last line](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/development/pystache/renderer.py#L221) of the rendering process.  (1) and (2) can both be easily done by the caller.  Removing markupsafe has the benefit of removing a dependency on an external library.  Also, requiring the user to provide the custom escape function is more consistent with Python's philosophy of "explicit rather than implicit."  Using the `try: import ... except: pass` pattern has the disadvantage that the user doesn't know whether markupsafe will be used or not.  Better to have the user specify and not fail silently.

items.title: Remove output_encoding option from Renderer, etc.
items.body: The output_encoding argument to Renderer() and View.render() doesn't seem to be worth holding on to.  All it does is cause `rendered.encode()` to be called with that encoding as the very last step of the rendering process.  We return unicode by default, so this can easily be done by the caller (especially if the caller has to write to a file anyways).  We will probably want to support a lot of rendering options, and it will help going forward to remove the ones we don't really need.

items.title: Use cgi.escape() with quote=True
items.body: We should escape double-quotation marks by default.

items.title: RenderEngine should operate only on unicode strings
items.body:
When markupsafe is importable, RenderEngine mixes operations between Markup strings and unicode strings.  This can (and has) lead to subtle double-escaping and related bugs, etc.  For clarity, RenderEngine should probably operate exclusively on unicode strings.  The conversion to Markup can take place afterwards.

We should also increase our test coverage to check for double-escaping and related issues when markupsafe is enabled.

items.title: Loader should accept decode_errors like Renderer
items.body: The Loader constructor should accept a decode_errors keyword argument like the Renderer class does.  It already supports an encoding argument.

items.title: Change Renderer to accept a loader implementing get()
items.body:
Changing `Renderer.__init__()` from accepting a load_template function to accepting a loader with a `get()` method will simplify the API a bit.  This will also make loading partials from a dictionary easier (and the same as passing a loader), since dictionaries implement get():

```
>>> partials = {'partial': 'Hello, {{thing}}!'}
>>> renderer = Renderer(loader=partials)
>>> renderer.render('{{>partial}}', {'thing': 'world'})
u'Hello, world!'
```

items.title: doctests should pass
items.body: Also, they should pass running `nosetests --with-doctest`.

items.title: Loader.load_template() should always return unicode
items.body: It's better to fail fast.

items.title: Renderer class should handle load_template not returning unicode
items.body: Make `Renderer.render()` more robust.  Currently, it can break if load_template returns a non-unicode string with non-ascii characters.  This is related to issue #10.

items.title: Support View attributes in Renderer class
items.body: The Renderer class should support the same template-related attributes that the View class supports (e.g. template_encoding and template_extension) -- e.g. when creating a default Loader.  This will bring template-rendering to parity with view-rendering.

items.title: Rename Template class to Renderer class
items.body:
The Template class is really more of a "rendering" class for storing all of the options on how to render a template string.

The attribute `self.template` is only used once in the class, and that's in the `Template.render()` method when it passes `self.template` to the `RenderEngine`.  So why not just pass the template string directly to `render()`?

This will make the API much simpler going forward.  For example, this will let us eventually pass `View` instances to `render()` (in addition to template strings), so that we won't have to repeat all of the rendering options a second time in the View class.

items.title: Create a RenderEngine class (make Template class smaller)
items.body:
We could simplify the code a bit by creating a RenderEngine class to house the rendering logic separate from the Template class.

This class would be used internally by the Template class and would operate only on unicode strings and Context instances.  The end-user wouldn't interact with the RenderEngine class directly.  The Template class would serve for now as the end-user API for the RenderEngine class and would do the necessary pre-processing (e.g. creating a Context instance) and post-processing (e.g. calling result.encode()).

This will also make it easier for us to focus on the rendering logic itself, because it will be more separate from less related considerations (separation of concerns).

items.title: Template.render() should convert templates to unicode
items.body:
This doesn't work yet (passing `Template()` an output encoding and a non-unicode template with non-ascii characters):

```
template = Template("déf", default_encoding='utf-8', output_encoding="utf-8")
template.render()
```

This is towards issue #10.

items.title: Change "disable_escape" to "escape" in Template.__init__()
items.body:
The constructor [`Template.__init__()`](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/e2ce832b01e78e1bb420e70315468aa19b2063ca/pystache/template.py#L63) should accept an optional `escape` function argument instead of the boolean `disable_escape`.  This is more natural.

Examples:
- Users wanting no escaping can pass `lambda s: s`.
- Non-markupsafe users wanting double-quotes escaped can pass `lambda s: cgi.escape(s, True)`.
- And similarly for markupsafe users wanting something other than [`markupsafe.escape()`](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/markupsafe/blob/98caea1496846935dd60a0e170c401e91ce9029a/markupsafe/_native.py#L14).

items.title: Add to Template() support for "encoding" and "errors"
items.body:
The Template class should support `encoding` and `errors` attributes (suitably named) that can be passed to [`unicode()`](http://docs.python.org/library/functions.html#unicode) and [`markupsafe.Markup()`](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/markupsafe/blob/98caea1496846935dd60a0e170c401e91ce9029a/markupsafe/__init__.py#L67) when converting Python `str`'s to unicode.

This is towards issue #10.

items.title: Allow unit testing both with and without markupsafe
items.body: We need a mechanism to allow testing of the Template class with markupsafe both enabled and not enabled.

items.title: Remove the context parameter from Template.__init__()
items.body:
Rather than passing the context to render to `Template.__init__()`:

```
template = Template(template, context, **kwargs)
rendered = template.render()
```

I think we should pass the context to render to `Template.render()`:

```
template = Template(template)
rendered = template.render(context, **kwargs)
```

This is conceptually clearer because the context to render is distinct from the template itself.

This also has at least a couple advantages from an API perspective:

(1) It lets you render multiple contexts with the same template:

```
template = Template(template)
rendered1 = template.render(context1)
rendered2 = template.render(context2)
```

(2) It also promotes a clean separation between Template options and the context `**kwargs`.  For example, we could do this:

```
template = Template(template, **options)
rendered = template.render(context, **kwargs)
```

Passing both template options and context `**kwargs` to `Template.__init__()` leads to the situation where adding a new Template option as a keyword argument always breaks backwards compatiblity (by potentially conflicting with context `**kwargs` that are already out in the wild).

items.title: Passing **kwargs to Template.__init__() modifies the context
items.body:
Passing `**kwargs` to `Template.__init__()` modifies the passed context:

```
context = {}
template = Template(context=context, foo="bar")
```

We should make a copy of the context inside `Template.__init__()` like we do [in `pystache.render()`](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/a484f30f593f1047a99c8361e19d5b3d3894790c/pystache/init.py#L21).

items.title: Template(foo="bar") raises an exception
items.body:
Passing `**kwargs` to `Template.__init__()` with no context raises an exception:

```
template = Template(foo="bar")
```

items.title: View class should not "own" the context

milestone.title: Template class should not depend on the View class
milestone.description: This was originally raised as part of issue #14.  But it has become a bigger issue since then.

items.body:
It seems like View instances should not "own" the rendering context (as [they currently do via `View.context_list`](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/22fbaa2b0d1bd225a5319679febcb4304c193ab1/pystache/view.py#L62)).

The context stack is part of the state used during the rendering process, and so would be more appropriately owned and managed by whatever is doing the rendering.  (Currently Template instances manage the rendering, for example [in the `Template._render_dictionary()` method](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/22fbaa2b0d1bd225a5319679febcb4304c193ab1/pystache/template.py#L148) by pushing and popping the context stack.)

Addressing this issue will help simplify the View class and better define separations of concern.

items.title: Template class should not depend on the View class

milestone.title: Template class should not depend on the View class
milestone.description: This was originally raised as part of issue #14.  But it has become a bigger issue since then.

items.body:
This is an issue placeholder for the milestone "Template class should not depend on the View class" -- for discussion purposes and so we can reference it.

It doesn't seem like GitHub lets one easily link to or discuss a milestone directly.

items.title: Allow partials to be passed as a dictionary
items.body: This issue is copied from issue #31 so that the two issues it raises can be handled and discussed separately.

items.title: Output of callables treated as template code
items.body:
This is caused by `_render_tags` operating on the output of `_render_sections`

Failing test:

``` python
def test_tag_in_labda_output(self):
    template = '{{#test}}Blah{{/test}}'
    context = {
        'test': lambda x: '{{hello}}'
    }
    ret = pystache.render(template, context)
    self.assertEquals(ret, '{{hello}}')
```

items.title: Seems to be treating context strings as templates
items.body:
``` python
import pystache
pystache.render('{{test}}', {'test':'Hello {{world}}'})
```

Outputs `Hello` while I'd expect `Hello {{world}}`. which is what http://mustache.github.com/#demo outputs.

Also means the following throws an error

``` python
import pystache
pystache.render('{{test}}', {'test':'Hello {{#world}}'})
```

items.title: Report spec compliance
items.body:
From the [Mustache spec](https://github.com/mustache/spec):

> Mustache implementations SHOULD report the most recent version of the spec (major and minor version numbers). If an implementation has support for any optional modules, they SHOULD indicate so with a remark attached to the version number (e.g. "vX.Y, including lambdas" or "v.X.Y+λ"). It is RECOMMENDED that implementations not supporting at least v1.0.0 of this spec refer to themselves as "Mustache-like", or "Mustache-inspired".

items.title: TemplateSpec should let one specify the template file path
items.body:
It seems like the View class should allow one to specify the path to the view's template file directly.

Currently, the only way to do this is to strip the extension from the file name and set this as the View instance's template_name, and then include the file's directory in a list of template directories and set this as the View instance's template_path, which seems more awkward than it needs to be.

Of course, the other way is to load the template yourself and pass it as a string, but this is also less convenient.

Related to this, the View class's template_path attribute would probably be better named something like template_dirs or template_search_dirs.  Indeed, the View class's get_template() method [passes self.template_path](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/f543efac93b753914a20b9daaf84a51382fba445/pystache/view.py#L48)--

```
self.template = Loader().load_template(template_name, self.template_path, encoding=self.template_encoding, extension=self.template_extension)
```

as Loader.load_template()'s [template_dirs parameter](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/f543efac93b753914a20b9daaf84a51382fba445/pystache/loader.py#L9):

```
def load_template(self, template_name, template_dirs=None, encoding=None, extension=None):
```

items.title: Allow template files to be extensionless
items.body:
Currently, pystache.loader.Loader.load_template() [adds a dot](https://github.com/defunkt/pystache/blob/f543efac93b753914a20b9daaf84a51382fba445/pystache/loader.py#L20) no matter what :

```
file_name = template_name + '.' + self.template_extension
```

items.title: maintainers?
items.body: Is anyone actively maintaining this repo anymore?  How do we go about reviving it?

items.title: mustache(5) documentation: clarify that non-false values inherit parent context
items.body:
The mustache(5) documentation isn't always explicit as to when the parent context should be inherited, though this seems to be implied in parts.  To reduce ambiguity, I think it would help to be more explicit on this point.

I don't know all the parts that need clarification, but here is one:

```
**Non-False Values**

When the value is non-false but not a list, it will be used as the
context for a single rendering of the block.
```

If my understanding is right, I think something like the following would be clearer:

```
**Non-False Values**

When the value is non-false but not a list, it will be used as the
context for a single rendering of the block.  This context should
also fall back to the parent context.
```

Thanks.

items.title: {{#x}}{{#x}}{{/x}}{{/x}} breaks
items.body:
You cannot work with objects such as the following due to pystache's reliance on regular expressions instead of a grammar:

`{documents: [{name:1, children:[{name: 2, children:[...]}]}]}`

Here's a test case that causes pystache to raise an exception:

http://pastebin.com/4eAYfyKD

items.title: Changing delimiters back is retroactive
items.body:
These two expressions should produce identical results, but don't:

```
>>> pystache.render('{{=$ $=}} {{hugged}} ', {})
' {{hugged}} '
>>> pystache.render('{{=$ $=}} {{hugged}} $={{ }}=$', {})
'  '
>>> 
```

items.title: multiline comments not working
items.body:
From: http://mustache.github.com/mustache.5.html

```
Comments may contain newlines.
```

Here is my testcase:

```
import pystache
print pystache.render('foo{{! baz }}bar')
print pystache.render('foo{{! \nbaz }}bar')
```

Expected output:

```
foobar
foobar
```

Current output:

```
foobar
foo{{! 
baz }}bar
```

Sugested fix:

``` diff
--- a/pystache/template.py
+++ b/pystache/template.py
@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ class Template(object):
         self.section_re = re.compile(section % tags, re.M|re.S)

         tag = r"%(otag)s(#|=|&|!|>|\{)?(.+?)\1?%(ctag)s+"
-        self.tag_re = re.compile(tag % tags)
+        self.tag_re = re.compile(tag % tags,re.DOTALL)

     def _render_sections(self, template, view):
         while True:
```

items.title: Add option to disable html escape
items.body: It would be nice to be able to generate raw text output for text emails for example. An option on the View to disable html escape altogether for example.

items.title: Support python2.5 on Google App Engine
items.body:
I knew the requirement is python2.6, but it's better to support python2.5. It will be more useful for  Google App Engine developers.
It only few lines change, I will attach the code later.

items.title: Mustache(5) example not working
Trunk sometimes escapes list blocks for no reason
items.body:
Every list block except the first one in the template has its contents escaped. ``` >>> pystache.render("

{{#this}}

{{/this}}

{{#that}}

{{/that}}

{{#other}}

{{/other}}

", {'this':[1,2], 'that':[1,2], 'other':[1,2]}) Markup(u'

<p><p>

<p><p>

') ``` You can't get the error by repeating the same block though: if it renders unescaped the first time, it will do the same thing the second time, and visa versa. ``` >>> pystache.render("

{{#this}}

{{/this}}

{{#that}}

{{/that}}

{{#this}}

{{/this}}

{{#that}}

{{/that}}", {'this':[1,2], 'that':[1,2]}) Markup(u'

<p><p>

<p><p>') ``` The error does not occur at tag 3.1. Just thought I'd make you guys aware of this.

items.title: Fails test "Nested (Truthy)" from Mustache Spec
items.body:
https://github.com/mustache/spec/blob/master/specs/sections.yml#L123

```
>>> import pystache
>>> pystache.render("| A {{#bool}}B {{#bool}}C{{/bool}} D{{/bool}} E |", {bool:True})
'| A  D E |'
```

items.title: custom delimeter in sections do not work
items.body:
this does not work:
    >>> pystache.render('{{=[[ ]]=}} hi [[#person]]person[[/person]]',{'person':'jack'})
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
      File "pystache/**init**.py", line 7, in render
        return Template(template, context).render()
      File "pystache/template.py", line 57, in render
        result = self.render_tags(template, context)
      File "pystache/template.py", line 113, in render_tags
        func = modifiers[tag_type]
    KeyError: '#'

items.title: New Maintainer?
items.body: Does someone want to take over? I'm not using Pystache in any projects.

items.title: not correctly handling 'Non-False Values'
Template path not propagated when rendering a partial inside a section
items.body:
Related to issue #8, if you put a partial within a section, it won't be able to find the template if you are using 'template_path' in your view.

outer.mustache

```
{{#somevalues}}
{{> rendervalues}}}
{{/somevalues
```

rendervalues.mustache:

```
{{name}}
```

If you set `template_path` in your view for outer.mustache, that template_path is not used to find rendervalues.mustache because though we are using a View, the values aren't 'inherited'.

Bug is in here:

```
@modifier('>')
def render_partial(self, tag_name=None, context=None):
    """Renders a partial within the current context."""
    # Import view here to avoid import loop
    from pystache.view import View

    view = View(context=context)
    view.template_name = tag_name

    return view.render()
```

In the above, the view 'settings' would be correctly copied over if `context` was a view, but since this is while rendering a section, context is something else.

The _real_ issue is the strange relationship between templates and views. As the comment above indicates, there is a 'loop' between views and templates... Really it's a bad case of tight coupling. Views need templates, and templates need views.

items.title: View executes callables wrongly
items.body:
View class always executes callable variables, it doesn't matter if it's a view's method or a lambda in the context dictionary.
Bug can be spotted by running the code in the following gist:
http://gist.github.com/522505

I wrote a test and code to fix it, as you can see in this compare view:
http://github.com/rafaelcv/pystache/compare/defunkt:49c34b...view_callable_bug
